awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: A Novel Method for Laminar Burning Speed Measurement at Ultra High-Pressures
awd_abstract_narration:
The next generation of advanced combustion devices will operate under ultra-high pressure conditions in order to improve the combustion efficiency and reduce emission of pollutants. However, at such extreme conditions, flame tends to become unstable and experimental measurement of fundamental properties becomes challenging. The principal aim of this project is to provide a detailed time- and space-resolved measurements of the ignition process at high pressures. In addition, the measurement methodologies and developed computational models will have a broad and valuable impact on combustion and plasma communities by enabling predictive capabilities for designing and optimizing advanced combustion devices operating under extreme conditions. The project will also encompass significant educational activities, including classroom and community engagement, integration of research into relevant courses, undergraduate research program, and an outreach program for K-12 students.

The main goal of this project is to develop a novel method to measure LBS in the ignition affected region using a spherically expanding flame under ultra-high pressures. The complication with this region is that, the kernel growth rate does not only depend on the chemical reaction but also on other terms such as energy discharge, as well as radiative and conductive energy losses. None of these terms has been adequately assessed, due to the generation of ionized gas (i.e., plasma). The proposed research will fill this broad knowledge gap via combined experimental and modeling studies focused in three specific aims: (1) using a well-defined and well-controlled high-pressure experimental configuration; (2) developing a self-consistent theoretical framework to explain the influence of energy discharge on the plasma formation and initial flame propagation; and (3) modifying an available high-fidelity direct numerical simulation (DNS) code to account for the evolution of the plasma kernel and the ignition process. On the experimental side, the project will utilize high-speed imaging of the plasma kernel propagation in conjunction with advanced laser diagnostics. The plasma properties will be calculated using statistical thermodynamics. This project, for the first time, aims to fundamentally understand the underlying physicochemical processes controlling the ultra-high pressure ignition in a high temporal and spatial resolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In the majority of thermal engines used in ground-based and aero-propulsion applications, ignition is achieved via spark discharge that produces high-temperature equilibrium plasma, which in turn activates the chemistry between fuels and oxygen. The physico-chemical processes at the early stages of plasma generation play a key role in the development of the so-called ignition kernel, whose growth affects the evolution of flames that are affected by both the plasma and combustion kinetics.

In the completed project, a computational framework was advanced that allows for the detailed modeling of the early formation and propagation of a flame kernel initiated from a plasma ignition source. Specifically, the earliest stages of ignition were modeled separately from the later involving kernel development. The ignition process begins with streamer propagation and breakdown of the gas between the electrodes. The resulting plasma equilibrates isochorically on the order of nanoseconds given the relaxation time scales of different energy modes (translational, rotational, vibrational, electronic) are significantly smaller than that of the fluid. The large difference in thermodynamic pressure between the breakdown kernel and the ambient gas forms a shockwave and rarefaction-wave, which mechanically expands the kernel on the order of microseconds. Finally, the remaining electrical energy is discharged into the conducting column of gas which undergoes Joule heating on the order of milliseconds. These three processes cover time scales that are many orders of magnitude apart and all need to be accounted for to properly model the early propagation of the plasma kernel.

Modeling of breakdown and the resulting shockwave were used to estimate the initial conditions of an in-house one-dimensional solver, which is then used to model the propagation of the plasma kernel. Ion and electron transport models were implemented, and a Joule heating source term was introduced as variable in time according to experimental data. Additionally, the heat loss from the electrodes were estimated using various models.

The above methods were used to simulate plasma discharge into air and CH4/N2 mixtures in conjunction with experiments done by our collaborators at Western Virginia University. Being able to properly model non-flammable mixtures is essential to capture the early ignition phase of flammable mixtures. Understanding the influence of the ignition kernel during kernel formation will facilitate extracting the laminar flame speeds during the early stages of ignition of spherically expanding flames at which the stretch rates are high and suppress the formation of hydrodynamic instabilities at high pressures.

 


Last Modified: 04/02/2023
Modified by: Fokion N Egolfopoulos
